Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

body:
context: i'm a systems/network engineer and have been tinkering with computers and networks since grade school. 

I also agree that #3 is the best plan, although a bit costly. In my home lab, i've been using typical 1U/2U HP servers for the past couple years, but they are quite loud (in my bedroom) and costly to operate since they do use a lot of power. I replaced them with a cluster of Intel NUCs with core i5's and 64GB of RAM each, and they're incredibly quiet and energy efficient (all 3 NUCs use less power than a single HP server), while getting some great performance.

I think a colocation provider would be willing to offer hosting for a cluster of well-specced mini PCs at a lower price due to the smaller footprint and lower power usage. You could probably even 3D print a 2U case to house them in.

Ruqqus should also consider purchasing an [AS number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)) from the ARIN, as well purchasing some decently sized IPv4 and IPv6 blocks with multiple peering agreements with different bandwidth providers. That way, even if a bandwidth provider (wholesale ISP) decides to deplatform Ruqqus, there wouldn't be much of an impact since Ruqqus owns the IP addresses, and the other providers will still be peered with them. Again, that is pretty costly but with the savings mentioned above it could work.

context: i'm a systems/network engineer and have been tinkering with computers and networks since grade school. 

I also agree that #3 is the best plan, although a bit costly. In my home lab, i've been using typical 1U/2U HP servers for the past couple years, but they are quite loud (in my bedroom) and costly to operate since they do use a lot of power. I replaced them with a cluster of Intel NUCs with core i5's and 64GB of RAM each, and they're incredibly quiet and energy efficient (all 3 NUCs use less power than a single HP server), while getting some great performance.

I think a colocation provider would be willing to offer hosting for a cluster of well-specced mini PCs at a lower price due to the smaller footprint and lower power usage. You could probably even 3D print a 2U case to house them in.

Ruqqus should also consider purchasing an [AS number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)) from the ARIN, as well purchasing some decently sized IPv4 and IPv6 blocks with multiple peering agreements with different bandwidth providers. That way, even if a bandwidth provider (wholesale ISP) decides to deplatform Ruqqus, there wouldn't be much of an impact since Ruqqus owns the IP addresses, and the other providers will still be peered with them. Again, that is pretty costly but with the savings mentioned above it could work.

body:
I used to run a "moral free" site getting 20 million page views a day, and I agree it's important for sites like Ruqqus to have full control over everything. Mainstream service providers are a non-starter. Their domain registrar can shut them down. Their bandwidth provider can shut them down. We owned our own IP block to ensure abuse complaints came straight to us instead of the company racking our servers.

On a related note, Ruqqus should have a DMCA takedown link in the sidebar right next to about, terms, etc. A content creator finding their stuff on the site could sink the ship with a long drawn out lawsuit. Ruqqus devs, take DMCA takedown requests seriously and keep records. It could save you later.

post.body:
Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

parent.body:
I used to run a "moral free" site getting 20 million page views a day, and I agree it's important for sites like Ruqqus to have full control over everything. Mainstream service providers are a non-starter. Their domain registrar can shut them down. Their bandwidth provider can shut them down. We owned our own IP block to ensure abuse complaints came straight to us instead of the company racking our servers.

On a related note, Ruqqus should have a DMCA takedown link in the sidebar right next to about, terms, etc. A content creator finding their stuff on the site could sink the ship with a long drawn out lawsuit. Ruqqus devs, take DMCA takedown requests seriously and keep records. It could save you later.

post.body:
Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

Imagine, a chan where no thread is ever removed with no jannies what so ever, easy to access as much as a simple click.

Mainstream service providers are a non-starter. Their domain registrar can shut them down. Their bandwidth provider can shut them down. Ruqqus devs, take DMCA takedown requests seriously and keep records. It could save you later.

Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

post.body:
Edit: links added

Hi Ruqqus and Ruqqus Devs,

I have noticed that Ruqqus runs on Heroku. This service is run by SalesForce, which has been known to use its terms and conditions to restrict user freedom. [For example, it does not allow users of its services to sell firearms of any sort.](https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/30/salesforce-bans-some-gun-sellers-from-using-its-software.html)

Since SalesForce has been known to do such things, it could try to deplatform Ruqqus in the future. Fortune 500 companies like Salesforce aren't exactly known for their amiability towards the sort of free speech absolutism that Ruqqus stands for. Not to mention that Heroku is rather unscalable and gets expensive pretty quickly, so if Ruqqus gets big then it will be difficult to keep running.

I think we could really use a contingency plan in case SalesForce tries to deplatform Ruqqus. 

I am a software developer by profession and I have three possible contingency plans in mind to elaborate on. Skip the rest of this paragraph to go right to them. Two if Ruqqus core devs really like Heroku-style easy deployments and one that can scale. All are easily transferrable to basically any hosting provider anywhere, and I made sure of that since big cloud providers (AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace/etc) have a known hostility to freedom. Examples being [AWS forcing Signal to decrease the accessibility of their platform around the world by using the AWS terms and conditions as a weapon](https://signal.org/blog/looking-back-on-the-front/), [Microsoft threatening to drop hosting for gab.ai and PayPal denying its services to gab.ai for "hate speech"](https://www.theverge.com/2018/8/9/17671188/microsoft-gab-hate-speech-hosting-ban-deplatform), and [RackSpace denying service to some pastor for burning copies of the Quran on the anniversary of 9/11, again using terms and conditions as a weapon, specifically against freedom of speech this time.](https://www.tgdaily.com/entertainment/web-hosting-firm-boots-out-book-burning-pastor/) There are also stories of all sorts of people getting deplatformed on Youtube for their speech, which I'm sure you're all aware of.

Hosting providers, Heroku included, would not hesitate to screw over Ruqqus if they could save themselves some bad press.

Edit 3: inserted here since it may be interesting to the dev team. Plans 1 and 2 probably cost *less* than Heroku in terms of money.

Plan 1 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (Dokku):

We could use Dokku, a free and open source self-hosted Heroku alternative, on any server we want. Pretty small footprint memory-wise. It supports Heroku buildpacks for deployment by default, which makes stuff really easy. However, this is not too scalable as you can't multi-host and load-balance. Dokku would be very easy though until Ruqqus gets big, at which point it would no longer be scalable.

Plan 2 - Heroku-style deployment without Heroku (CapRover): 
We could use CapRover instead of Dokku, another free and open source self-hosted Heroku clone that is also easy to use. The great part is that you can use multiple servers, do load balancing, and it has a GUI for management if you want to use it unlike Dokku among other things. The only unfortunate part is that it doesn't support Heroku-style buildpacks.

Plan 3 - OpenStack (open-source alternative to AWS/Azure/Google Cloud Platform/RackSpace):

This is the most scalable idea, but also has the most overhead and the most cost so this is definitely not what we want for now. The reason I include it is to make the core dev team aware that it exists. Think of it as a free (though hosting it has a cost) and open-source version of AWS, with compute/containers/functions/object and block storage/load balancer/identity/DNS service/clustering/alarms/databases/everything. *Most importantly, infrastructure-as-code platforms like Terraform and Chef support it so it can be automatically assembled anywhere if we had/needed the resources to host it*. It is less documented since less people use it, but documentation is sufficient enough that it is usable to an experienced generalist developer (and even moreso for a devops specialist).

I am not asking for a rework of Ruqqus to be very clear, it's fine as-is for now. But I really think the Ruqqus dev team should have a backup plan to avoid being deplatformed (and get up and running again within a day-ish if it does happen). I can help with this if it is ever desired, but in the meantime I'll just do PRs on Github to help out with the current Ruqqus. Just discovered this platform yesterday though so it will be a bit before I'm useful.

EDIT 2: Something else the Ruqqus devs may want to consider is moving from Github to a self-hosted Gitlab instance, since its CI/CD tooling is better and you can't get your codebase deplatformed (Github has done repo takedowns before)

Honestly. I would love to see this type of platform on a deep web. I know that this might have some illegal implication, but if admins promise to keep the platform legal within the bounds of free speech. I don't think there would be any problems.     
But it would be a better solution for the free internet.     
It would also be a better platform for whistleblowers, political refugees etc.      
Specially if you keep it hashed and safe, with private and public keys.     
     
Maybe in the opening days, you might not want to host pictures and videos, just text and link to the normie web.    
     
But this would also be a step to building truly open internet. As it was supposed to be.

body:
From a technical point of view, the simplest migration to a vendor neutral setup would be something like this:

1. Update the Heroku configuration to simply build a [Docker image](https://devcenter.heroku.com/articles/build-docker-images-heroku-yml) for deployment, this an instant win as it requires no infra/vendor changes, is pretty straightforward (an hour or so?), and immediately takes out any real reliance on Heroku going forward. 

2. Going off of your suggestion of CapRover, have a few instances with different providers - i.e *x* instances split between AWS, GCP etc. Dirty basic VMs running the above docker containers, in this case . 

3. Keep low TTL values on DNS records, and alternative between providers via DNS records based upon liveness tests. Using the cloudflare API you could likely rig up something in Python in about 15 mins to perform a health check periodically and update appropriately. 

As you point out, long term you'd go for something like terraform so you don't actually need any redundant resources, and you can provision them as and when required. I think the above 3 steps are relatively simple in the shorter term though, and provide a solid vendor-agnostic approach. (with the exception of cloudflare admittedly.)

The hardest bit will be cross-cloud replication of Postgres IMO, although I'm assuming Redis can be treated as ephemeral, and its contents safely lost in the event of an emergency. I remember trying to configure Redis with redundancy in mind before, and I ended up being lazy and just using GCPs managed Redis offering.

From a technical point of view, the simplest migration to a vendor neutral setup would be something like this:

  1. Update the Heroku configuration to simply build a Docker image for deployment, this an instant win as it requires no infra/vendor changes, is pretty straightforward (an hour or so?), and immediately takes out any real reliance on Heroku going forward.

  2. Going off of your suggestion of CapRover, have a few instances with different providers - i.e x instances split between AWS, GCP etc. Dirty basic VMs running the above docker containers, in this case .

  3. Keep low TTL values on DNS records, and alternative between providers via DNS records based upon liveness tests. Using the cloudflare API you could likely rig up something in Python in about 15 mins to perform a health check periodically and update appropriately.

As you point out, long term you'd go for something like terraform so you don't actually need any redundant resources, and you can provision them as and when required. I think the above 3 steps are relatively simple in the shorter term though, and provide a solid vendor-agnostic approach. (with the exception of cloudflare admittedly.)

The hardest bit will be cross-cloud replication of Postgres IMO, although I'm assuming Redis can be treated as ephemeral, and its contents safely lost in the event of an emergency. I remember trying to configure Redis with redundancy in mind before, and I ended up being lazy and just using GCPs managed Redis offering.
